question: Question_04_(a)
statement:
The temperature at a point (x,y,z) is given by

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}T(x,y,z)=5\exp(-2x^2-y^2-3z^2)\end{align*}

where T is measured in centigrade and x,y,z in metres.

Find the rate of change of temperature at the point P(1,2,-1) in the
direction toward the point (1,1,0).
sols:
For $\displaystyle {}T(x,y,z) = 5 e^{-2x^2 - y^2 - 3z^2}$, the gradient
is

\begin{align*}
\nabla T(x,y,z) &= 5 e^{-2x^2 - y^2 - 3z^2}\left\langle{-4x, -2y, -6z}\right\rangle \\
&= 10e^{-2x^2 - y^2 - 3z^2}\left\langle{-2x, -y, -3z}\right\rangle\end{align*}

At the point $\displaystyle {}P(1,2,-1)$, we have $\nabla T(1,2,-1)
= 10 e^{-9}\left\langle{-2,-2,3}\right\rangle.$ Each component has units
of $\displaystyle {}\text{C}/\text{m}$.

The vector from $\displaystyle {}P(1,2,-1)$ to $\displaystyle {}Q(1,1,0)$
is $\displaystyle {}\left\langle{0,-1,1}\right\rangle$

A unit vector in this direction is

\begin{align*}\widehat{\mathbf{u}} = \frac{\left\langle{0,-1,1}\right\rangle}{\left\vert\left\langle{0,-1,1}\right\rangle\right\vert} = \frac{1}{\sqrt2}\left\langle{0,-1,1}\right\rangle\end{align*}

Each component is dimensionless because the units of the vector
$\mathbf{u}$ and its magnitude are the same.

The rate of change of \emph{T} at \emph{P} in direction
$\displaystyle {}\widehat{\mathbf{u}}$ is

\begin{align*}
D_{\widehat{\mathbf{u}}} T(1,2,-1)
= \nabla T(1,2,-1)\cdot\widehat{\mathbf{u}}
= 10 e^{-9}\left(\frac{5}{\sqrt2}\right)
= 25\sqrt2 e^{-9}.\end{align*} Its units are $\displaystyle {}\text{C}/\text{m}$.
hints:
Recall that the directional derivative of a scalar function f in the
direction $\mathbf{u}$ is

\begin{align*}D_uf=\nabla{f}\cdot\hat{\mathbf{u}}\end{align*}

where $\hat{\mathbf{u}}$ is a unit vector.
What is the direction vector $\mathbf{u}$ that we need?
